mods.note: I1916. NOTES. Volume III, Routes in Persia, lias now been broken up into two parts. Part I comprises routes in South- West Persia east of a line drawn from Bandar Dilam through Behbehan and just east of Narghun to Isfahan. Part II comprises routes in South-West Persia west of the above line and those in a small part of Turkey in Asia. Simla ; »/ 2 Route No. 1— contd. Ko. of stage and total distance. Details, 1 ——, ■ -- ■ ■ ■ »— * CHAH-I-’ ALI .. H nl. General direction K 11 m. The road crosses a wide open sandy plain to 1 mile, where the bed of a nala is entered and descended. The banks gradually increase in height until at 1 J miles it joins a wide ravine with a sandy bottom and rocky sides about 30 feet high. The track now ascends out of the ravine, and runs along a fairly straight depression in a plateau showing a gentle sloping surface to the east, and perpendicular broken edges to the west. The track now descends into another nala at TJ miles, which is crossed close to its junction with a larger immediately on the right of the track. The ascent from the nala is somewhat steeper than the descent. The going is over sheets of sandstone rock. At 5 miles, a rough plateau is reached, over which the track lies to about 8 miles. There are low rocky ridges about 500 yards away to the right, and on the left, the plateau ends in a precipitous, and broken edge, which sinks down into a large water-course on that side. The ground undulates a good deal, but throughout the changes of level, the surface is always the same sheet of solid sandstone rock. At 8 J- miles the track descends into another large water-channel coming in from the right by a steep and narrow path. This is crossed by a ford just below its junction with another nala coming in from the opposite side. The track now ascends the latter to 9J miles. The bed is some 200 yards wide., full of huge stones, and bordered by scarps about 40 feet high. At 94 miles the nald forks, and the track runs up the smaller and left-hand branch, which is extremely rough and rocky. This ravine leads up to the west of Chah-i-’AlI. Caravans instead of halting at Chah-i-’Ali, frequently stop at Tsin, which lies about 2 miles to the west, and consists of 150 houses. Water. —Good but limited from qxndts. Supplies .—Practicallv nil. 2 GINAU .. .. 12 m. General direction N. 23 m Leaving Chah-i - 5 All the road at 1 J miles1 3 Route No- 1 — contd. crosses a large water-channel running from east. The route now lies up the left bank of another ravine, which joins that just crossed a little below the road, to If miles, and then comes out on to a rough stony plateau over which the going is bad. At 7 f miles a low long stone db-ambdr lies to the west of the road, after which the going improves. At 9 J miles the track branches. The road following the left branch crosses a small ridge at 10 J miles, and almost immediately afterwards, leaving the plain, proceeds westerly, following the course of a gorge, over a rather steep and indifferent track. At 12 miles a small plain is reached among hills, where is a palm grove and a water tank. The water runs dry every summer. Close by is a spring strongly impregnated with sulphur. The village of Ginau lies about half a mile further on ; it consists of a few houses ; there are four or five miles turned by water. Water ,—Foul from a tank. Between April and the first fall of rain, would have to be brought. Fodder ,—Grazing scarce. Supplies .—Practically nil. 3 SARZEH .. 16 m. General direction N.-W. The track leaves the 39 m. water tank, along a broad road easily passable for all arms. After some palm groves, strike north towards an db-ambdr, at 2 miles, around which are a few huts. The water is sweet. The right bank of a broad shallow ndld, on the right of the road, is reached at 4 miles. The water in this ndld is said to be brackish. The Kuh-i-Ginau lies 2-3 miles, off to the left, and another range 5-6 miles off to the right. The track now crosses an undulating upland plain, which slopes down from the Kuh-i-Ginau; the going varies, gra dually improving and descending. At 8 J miles a dry water course is crossed, with steep banks and a stony bed, which joins a river about half a mile to the east. At 10|: miles the track descends by a gentle gradient to a lower plateau, which con tinues undulating and broken to Ilf miles. From hereto 14-f miles the going is good, at first over sandy clay and then over gravel. At 14J miles a river, containing fresh water, is crossed. The river lies about 40 feet below the level of the plian, and its left bank, in some parts is a rocky scarp. The route now lies up a rocky ravine on to an open plain of sandy gravel. The river flows on the left, 100 yards distant, and on the right is the4 . Route No. 1— end of a rocky spur or ridge. Just before reaching vi ■of Sarzeh, at 16 miles, the river has again to he lorded. I he village consists of a few scattered huts. Water .—Good and abundant from river Fodder .—Grazing scarce. Supplies -—Very scarce. 4 ZURATU •• 18 m. and/or the last quarter N.-W. Follow the right bank of the stream for 1 mile. From here the track runs across the plain keeping a ridge continuously on the right. The pia known as the Sahra-i-Dardam, is 4-5 miles wide, and is follow ed for 8 miles. At 2f miles a river-bed with a stony channel, 100 yards wide, is crossed. The road now runs over the stony plain to about 6 | miles, where it bends to the left round the end of a spur of a long rocky ridge. On the other side of the spur the road drops into a river-bed which is con tinually crossed and recrossed up to 11 nul#s. At 12 ^ miles a small palm grove is passed some few hundred yards off to the left. The open plain of Barak is on the right. At 14J miles the village of Gishan is passed 2-3 miles off to the right. On the right commences a great ridge of sloping strata which runs para - lei to the track. The river runs all the way parallel on the right to 161- miles, where it is crossed. An ascent of 100 feet is now made to a stony plateau, 200 yards broad, and having a broad water-course on either hand. At 18 miles the hamlet of Zuratu is reached. It lies immediately under the range of smooth hills which bounds the S.-W. side of the valley. Water Good and abundant from a spring at the base ot General direction for the first three-quarters of the stage J5.-E. the hill. Supplies.—Very scanty. 5 ABM ARC AMP.. M|m. General direction - W.-N.-W. Proceed up the vallqy over a stony upland and descend gradually over undulating ground. At 3 miles a ndM is crossed and an ascent made to the top of a small Icutcd at 4 miles. At H miles a tributary flows into the water course on the left. The track lies down the river-bed, which is narrow, and the going bad. At 6 miles the river widens out and the road continues across a more open stony plain. The * ‘ j5 Route No. 1 — palm groves of Guhra now come in sight. The direct road to Ab Mar leaves Guhra on the west, and makes for the village of Kutabad. At 7 | miles a river-bed is crossed, and an ascent made over a stony plain on the far side. At 9 miles is the village of Kutabad. From here the route lies up a gradually narrowing valley bounded on the east by conglomerate and mud cliffs. The going is stony. At 12 miles the hamlet of Narakun is passed on theS.-W. 300 yards off the road. Here the valley narrows, and at 12 | miles begins to widen again. The road now crosses from the S.-W. to the N.-E. of a valley lying close under a hill, at 141 miles. Thence across the valley again over stony ground to Ab-Mar, lying on the N.-E. side of the valley at 16J miles. Here are a few houses. It is better to go on another 4-| miles further north, where there is a little water in a nala ; it shortens the next stage. Leaving Ab Mar, direction N.-E., the valley widens out into an open plain bounded on the N.-E. by a lofty range. The road then swings round and assumes a northerly direction, a ridge of hills being close ont he right. From here the route lies over a stony plateau for about a mile and then drops down into a nala by the left bank. A few' hundred yards further on, a trickle of sweet water emerges from shale in the bottom of the nald. There is a good camping-ground on the left bank above this water. It is not stated whether this water is perennial. The time of year, at which the trickle was found as stated, was in the beginning of April. Camping ground .—Good 4-| miles N. of Ab Mar . Water .—Good but limited. Supplies. —Scarce. 6 ' SA’ADATABAD .. 24 m. General direction for the first half of the stage 971 . m< N.-E., for the latter hall'N.-W. The route continues to follow the bed of the ndld for 4 or 5 miles. The E. side of the ndld consists of a limestone range. Thence to 4-|- miles undulating ground is traversed, where anotheroruZu is entered and ascended for half a mile. The track then emerges by the left bank on to a plateau, and a Jcutal is reached after a few hundred yards. From here the road descends over an undulating stony plain for 2-3 miles. To the left front can be seen the point of the range which marks the entrance to the Tang-i-Zagh. There is a rather steep descent,Koute No. 1— contd. for the first quarter of a mile, and then stony going. At 12 miles the track lies in a stony river-bed in a valley with limestone hills on either side. A sharp turn to the left and gradually descend into the Tang-i-Zagh, which continues 14J miles. The going is bad ; there are narrow points, and in w r et weather the gorge would not be passable. It is irn- . practicable for anything on wheels, and it is difficult for pack animals : serious operations would have to be undertaken to make a rough path. At 14| miles, the Tang-i-Zagh ends in a defile. The track continues down the ndld to 15 miles, where it leaves by the right bank, and thence continues the descent over a stony plain which gradually widens. The plain is covered with scrub and bushes. The track follows the course of a qandt. At 19 miles, a ndld is crossed and the route swings round some hills into the Tang-i-LambI, which is a winding ravine with precipitous sides. At 24 miles the village of Sa’adatabad is reached. It is a village of some 3,000 inhabitants lying outside the walls of a fort. There is much cultivation a short distance to the W. Water .—Good and abundant from a well, and at times from a stream . Supplies. —Scarce. 7 GAKUM .. 12 m. General direction N. by — W. The village of 109J m. Gakum lies at the N.- E. extremity of the alluvial plain, in the S.-E. corner of which lies the village of Sa’adatabad. The route at first lies over a stony plain, gently ascending, and at 3 J miles the remains of a former town is passed among jungle. It is. known as Sar-i-Chahan and is now nothing but mud heaps. At 4 miles a ruined mud tower is passed 500 yards to the right of the road. The going is good. At 4| miles the jungle ceases, and the track continues good, over pat, iov the rest of the stage. The direction is towards a volcanic mass lying at the base of the range bounding the N.-E. side of the plain. The range is the Kuh-i-Gakum. At 6 J miles the volcanic mass is reached and passed to the right. At 8 | miles the road strikes across the plain for the corner of the Gakum date groves. At 11 miles the date groves are reached, and at 12 miles the village of Gakum. There is a fort surrounded by a fair number of houses..7 V* v . r .. ~\f rT Route No. Camping ground—At Zlarat-i-Zalri-ul-Afcd-ud Din, 1 m. N. of villacre. Water—Goo& and abundant from a well. Supplies, —Scarce. 8 HAJIABAD .. 14 m. General direction '— X.-X.-E. Leaving the 1231 m. Zlarat, the road makes for a rocky spur of the Gakvim range at 1 mile, over pat. Pass ing this the route swings X. and makes for a ruined caravanserai at 2 miles. At 3 miles, the track leaves the plain, and ascends a gorge up a rough stony track, afterwards emerging on to a small plain, which is traversed in a north-westerly direction for 600 yards, where there is a sharp and bad descent into a river-bed, the direction changing to X.-E. At 4 miles the track again drops into the river-bed and ascends the course of the river, 'which is here enclosed between rocky sides. At 44 miles the route leaves the river-bed, thence continuing for one and a half miles over undulating country. Spurs of the Kuh-i-Gakum close in on the right. At 6 miles there is another drop into the river-bed ? at a point where it makes a deep bend northward. The stream is crossed twice and then the track continues alon£ the left bank. At 7 miles the centre of the water-course becomes very marshy. At 9 miles there is some cultivation, and a palm grove, on the left bank of the river. The bed now narrows down as the road nears Hajlabad, and the going is generally bad. At 12 miles, the tiny village of Kuldan is passed ; the village is on the right bank, and the road a short distance from the left bank. At 13 miles the track crosses to the right bank of the river. At 13| miles there is a palm grove on the E. of the road, which crosses a, water-course from the Tang-i-Xiza. At 14 miles the village of Hajiabad is reached. The village, built round a ruined mud fort on a mound, has extensive date groves, and cultivation. Camping ground, —X. of the village, across the natd running S. from the Tang-i-Xiza. Water ,—Good and abundant, S uppli es. — S c ar ee, 9 KUKAN ., 28 m. General direction X.-X.-W. The route 1514 m. lies direct towards the Tang-i-Xiza, which is entered at about 2 miles. The going“***- 8 Route No. 1— contd. ; is stony, and mountains lie close on either hand. At 6 miles, a water-mill is passed, and at 7 miles the village of Mza. _ 8 miles there are cultivation, palms, and wells on o si es tang. At 10 miles the road leaves the left bank of the na and ascends over an open plain, crossing the river-bed at 11 miles from left to right, and then over an open plain. At 13 miles the track again crosses the river, and keeps close under a ridge on ne right hand. The road continues up this river-bed, on one bank or the other, and often in the actual river-bed. At 17 mi es a rocky hill is passed immediately to the right. At ^ g mi es a larger rocky hill, rising about 1,000 feet above the river-bed, is passed, also to the right. At 27 miles the small fortified village of Muhammadabad, with a palm grove and cultivation. At miles the village of Hajlabad with a palm grove, cultivation and zicirat. Then the route lies up the bed of the stream. At -8 miles, the village of Kukan is reached, which lies about quarter of a mile off to the E. of the road over a small ridge which hides it. The village cultivation lies to the E. in a valley. Water.—Good from spring, but limited. Supplies. —Limited. , . , T 10 CHAH GABRISTAN 21 m. General direction J\. The road proceeds up m the valley o\ er ston^y and 2 undulating ground ; the valley here is about a mile wide. At miles the road mounts a small rise, from which P 0111 ! 1 the 'hills of Chah-i-Chagak come into view 9 miles ahead across a gentlv rising plain. On the left there is a tower on a u - top ; the Chah-i-Chagak pass lies just under this tower to the E At 5 miles about half a mile W. of the road, there is a small pool of stagnant water in a qanat. At 6 miles a ruined tower is passed to the E. of the road. The route lies over a slightly undulating and gently rising plain, overgrown with scrub, making in a northerly direction towards the mountains. At 10 miles the ascent increases. At Hi miles there is a well of sweet water under a tree 50 yards to the W. of the track, known as the Chah Kisur. The ascent continues rather steeper, but never difficult, over a well-wooded mountain slope. At 12 miles the Gudar-i-Chah-i-Chagak is reached. There is a gradual descent over well-wooded and somewhat undulating country. At 13J miles the track enters a fairly level plain with a gradual9 Koute No. l~contd. descent. Tiic well of Olutli-i-lies to the E. of the TOci d. At 19J miles the point of the spur of a range lying on the N.-N.- W. is passed. At 21 miles Chah Gabristan is reached lying under the S. face of a limestone ridge. Water .—Good but limited, from a well. ~ Fodder .—Grazing plentiful. Supplies. — Nil. 11 MALIKABAD .. 23 m. General direction N. ^ The track makes for a 195 2 - m. _ spur 5 miles distant, which cuts into the plain from a range on the W.; it is known as the Puzeh-i-Kham. At 3 | miles there is a well not easily noticed among the scrub. At 5 miles the Puzeh-i-Kham is reached. Up to here the plain is covered with scrub, but beyond Puzeh- i-Kham it is pat without any vegetation. The direction is N. There is a range on the left which is gradually quitted. For the next 10 miles, there is bare level pat. At 15 miles the track enters scrub. At 17 miles a ruined fort is passed on the left of the road. At 21 miles the fortified village of Amirabad. At 23 miles Malikabad is reached, which is a large village with a strongly built fort lying at the southern edge of the village. Caraping ground .—In gardens | mile S. of the fort. Water. —Good and abundant from qandt in the gardens, and from a well in the fort. Supplies. —Scarce. 12 2104 m. SAIDABAD 5,510'. 15 m. General direction N. The stage lies over a good track, over a level plain, and the going is good. At If miles the village of Uzidabad is passed and at 3] : miles the village of Ibrahim- abad, a small village with numerous gardens, and a newlv constructed tower standing among ruins about a quarter ofa mile to the N. To the rights front is the Ziarat of Shah Firuz 3-4 miles distant. At 7 miles ruined village is passed. At 7J miles the track runs to the W. of the Kaleh-i-Sang, a white limestone ridge, about three-quarters of a mile distant. At Si miles the village of Kamalabad is passed, at I 0 | miles the track runs through the village of Najafabad. From here to Saidabad, at 15 miles, the track runs over a level plain, and numerous villages with gardens are passed on the W of the Cl(w)G3B10 Route No. l—contd. »> road. Saidabad, the chief town of Sirjan with a population of 12 ? 000 , is a town of importance, containing bazars. Water—Qoodi and abundant from qanats. Fuel. —Scarce. Fodder .—Grazing scarce ; none in winter. Supplies. —Plentiful. 13 SA’ADATABAD .. 16| m. General direction N.-E* 6,320'. The road is an excel- 227 m. lont track over a sandy plain. In places the plain is cultivated and towards the end of the stage it is very stony. At 8 f miles an db-ambdr is passed. The road throughout the stage leads almost directly on to the Kuh-i-Khan-i-Surkh, which can be seen in the distance. At 16J miles the village of Sa’adatabad is reached, which is fairly large (population 3,000) and has a caravanserai. Water .—Good and abundant from stream and wells. Supplies.- —Scarce. 14 KHAN-I-SUR&H.. 27 m. General direction 7 ? 800'. N.-E. The track lies 254 m. over a plain in some parts stony, and as the mountains are approached the track becomes undulating. The route at first lies on the crest of one of the low wave-like ridges thrown out from the mountain chain in front. At 7J miles the road descends into the dry bed of a water-course, where it becomes rather stony. The water-course is ascended ; the ascent is easy and the road is good. At 1 1 miles a stream, with irrigation channels, is reached, where there is some cultivation. At llj miles the road enters into the mountains, and a mud hovel known as the Bid-i-Khwah is reached. The stream is still ascended, being closely shut in by steep hills. In the bed are a good many trees. Then a more open country, although somewhat hilly, amongst the mountains is reached. The hills are gently sloping and there is a good deal of cultivation, but there are no habitations of any kind. At 18 miles the road ascends, but the track is good. At 19J miles the solitary caravanserai of Sang-i-Tu is passed. At 20| miles the Gudar-i-Surkh is reached, the ascent being easy. The peak of the Kiih-i-Surkh is about 400 yards distant to the E.Route No. The route descends along gently sloping hills, following the bed ot a dry water-course in northerly direction. From the bed of the water-course, the point of a spur on the right is rounded and a large valley, running N.-E. and S.-W., is gained, and immediately afterwards the caravanserai of Khan-i-Surkh. There are no habitations. Water, Good and abundant from stream and well. Fuel ,— Fodder .— Supplies .— 15 MASHlZ .. 29£ m. General direction ^ 6,610. E.-N.-E. The track 283f m. li es down a narrow valley between low hills. At 3 miles there is an irrigation stream with plenty of water. At 9| miles there is water near the road. At 10 miles the valley opens, and afterwards a wide valley opens out to left running up towards the N.-W. and the W. At 111 - miles there is an irrigation channel of good water. At 13} miles the road runs between low hills; there is some scrub and small thorny bushes. The road now lies directly on the peak of the Kuh-i-Mashlz. This mountain is a long one with several peaks ; the \ illage of Mashiz lies to the E. of it. The road continues down an open valley, bounded by low hills with scrubby thorns. At 18} miles a broad channel is crossed near a ruined fort, with a stream of good water in it, and a little cultivation. This might be made a halting point for troops. A few villages are passed on the right, and at 21 miles the ruins of Kaleh Muhammadabad is seen on the right. At 22 } miles there is a descent and on the left of the road are the remains of a small square fort, while on the right is Gurnai, a small village. The going now is more undulating. At 23} miles there is a zidrat. A track to BaJ> ramabad here goes off to the N. A little further on is the vil lage of Kahnu, and at 23f miles the village of Pulnabad onthe left of the road. At 25 miles a dry water-course is crossed, about 230 yards broad. The track lies over a good gravel plain. At about 28 miles three water-courses are crossed. At 29} miles the cluster of villages of Mashiz is reached in open plain in the broad Bardslr valley. Water.—Goodi and abundant from qandts. Supplies, —-Scarce,Route No. l—contd. 16 AKBARABAD . . 28 m. General direction N.-E. The road gradually 309^ m. ascends over the plain and at 1 mile a small village is passed on the left of the road. At 2J miles the Ab-i-Lalehzar, a good stream of water, is crossed. At 4 miles the road enters low hills, and ascends easily out of the broad Bardslr valley to 6 | miles, where a little pass leads into a small plain ; this is about a couple of miles wide, and is crossed in a north-easterly direction. The plain is bare. At Sj miles the plain is quitted by another small pass, and then the road lies amongst low [rocky hills still rising easily, to the first crest of the Gudar-i-Bukhtar, from which there is a nasty stony descent. The bottom, which is 300 feet .below the crest, is succeeded by a somewhat steep climb to the second pass at tne same altitude as the first. This is gained at 94 miles, and the track runs down a narrow and rocky defile to the caravanserai of Khan-i-Kuh, which is reached at 11 | miles. Directly beyond the caravanserai the road to Baglnn branches off to the left. I he road leads down the defile, and at 13 1 miles, an immense plain is reached, stretching N.-E. to Akbarabad and Baghm, the former of which is visible from here [11 miles distant]. At 174 miles a line of qandt wnlls is reached, stretching up and down the plain as far as can be seen: at 194 miles another line of qandts, and an abandoned fort a mile the right of the road. The plain up to this is bare; from here it is clothed with thorn and tufts. At 224 miles the Rud-i-Chari is crossed flowing from the S.-E. At 23 miles cultivation commences. The vil lage of Baghln lies two miles to the left at the base of a mountain. The S.-E. end of the mountain is close to the village. At 24 miles there is an irrigation stream of fresh water, and the road turns sharp round to the E. to the villages of Akbarabad and Khair- abad. The villages of Akbarabad and Khairabad are wretched places. Water. —Good and abundant from qandts. Supplies. —Scarce. Some could be collected from the neighbourhood. 17 KIKMAM •• 14J m, General direction N.-E. — 5,550b The track lies over 324m. a bare sandy plain where the going is heavy, and progress is rather slower than usual,13 Route No. 1— contd. To the right the plain stretches a great distance to high mountains. At 5b miles cultivation begins and there is a good stream of clear water. Here the plain of Kirman begins to open up to the left at the back of the hill which the road has been skirting. At about 9 miles, the main road from Yazd, via Bahramabad, joins in on the left. At 9-| miles there is a well and a rest-house, from which point the first sight of the city of Kirman is obtained. From here the cultivation is continuous until the town is reached, which is entered at the Yazdi gate close to the drlc or palace of the Governor. . v > • ’• • •>.» A From BANDAR ’ABBAS to GINAU (Stage’ 2) via CHAH CHAKUR. 23 miles. 2 stages. Authority.- —Shakespear, 1906. Epitome. This is a better route. Wheeled transport could traverse it with a little spade work. No. of stage and total distance. Details. go lira n .1 t 1 CHAH CHAKUR 11 m. Road goes via Nakhl ^ ' Nakhuda, and 1 mile 1 1 m . beyond turns N. Then bad country is met with consisting of a sandstone ridge in which the track is shown by deep ruts. Passing this a gravelly soil is entered upon and a plain in which the village of Chah Chakur lies. Several ted places and ndids, but a road passabla for guns could be made by 100 men in two days. Camping ground .—Good at Kurmudar. Water .—Good from a qandt. {Supplies.- — Nil, except dates.14 Route No. 1— contd. 2 GINAU .. 12 m. General direction N. by W. Leave plain and 23 m. proceed along river bed till Hurmudar is reached with extensive date groves. Road then over gravelly sloped plateaux, intersected at intervals by ndlds with steep sides and boulders, which would require work to be made passable for guns. At 8 miles a long stone water reservoir in good order is met. Good road from here to Ginau Hill at 10 miles. Road goes over this by a fair road, but the descent is rather bad for J mile. Track becomes a broad stony road, passable for all ams. From MASHIZ (Stage 15) to KIRMAN via BAGHlN. 44 miles. 2 stages. Epitome. This is four miles longer than the other. Baghin however has more supplies than Akbarabad. Xo. of stage; and total distance. Details. 1 BAGHIN .. 26 m. Genera] direction N.-E. 5,879'. The route for the first 26 m. \l\ miles identical with that given in the main route. Just beyond this point near the caravanserai of Khan-i-Kuh, the track branches off to the left front, and runs down the bed of a shallow ravine, about 50 yards across. At about 15 miles the track emerges from the foot hills and then runs across a clay soil, with a thin crust of gravel and devoid of vegetation. At 2 If miles the main drainage channels of the valley is crossed. It turns from S.-E. to N.-W., and is shallow, without perceptible banks, and a gravelly bottom. After passing the river, the track lies over sandy soil, wdiich 'would be heavy for guns to 2 If miles, where cultivation com mences. At 26 miles the village of Baghin (250 houses) is reach ed, situated on the base of a mountain which runs N.-W. and S.-E. Water .—Brackish from qavdts. Fuel. —Fair. Supplies. —Plentiful.15 Route No. l~concld. 2 KIRMAN .. 18 m. General direction E.-N.- ~~ ‘ E. Leaving Baghm m * _ and crossing a line of deep qanats the road lies over undulating ground mostly gravel and sand. lor the first two miles or so the route lies through cultivated ground. Cultivation, however, continues down the centre of the valley, whilst the road turns N.-E., and, rounding an outlying red spur, passes close to the base of the hills on the left. At this point the village af Akbarabad lies some two miles t° the right of the road. There is some heavy sand going, follow ed by clay, until it nears the little village of Sa’adatabad, at about 11 miles. The village lies about a quarter of a mile to the north of the road. The clay belt, which has to be crossed, becomes a regular swamp in rain or after the melting of the snow. At 12 J miles there is a well and a rest-house, and a little before this point is reached the road from Akbarabad comes in on the right. Epitome, ■ •' T V / . : : i .t. v l : _ .. ... i , •• if ff : ■: . \ \ \ , , T Tiiis route appears to be a connecting route between the two main routes to Kirman and Yazd. Epitome. This is the main caravan route between Kirman and Shiraz It is suitable for camel transport and ivould be suitable for wheeled artillery if widened and levelled. Between stages 5 and 10 the road is more or less a level desert. Stages 1 to 5 run through hilly country, but, wiih a small amount of labour, the road would be quite passable for artillery ; Stages 6 to 10 are across a practically level desert and there does not appear that there would be any obstacle to the passage of guns. Stages 11 to 14 the road is level or slightly undulating, the greater part being stony. Between Khan-i-Khit and the point called Pul-i-Talkh, the road passes through low hills where the present track is too narrow for wheels. At Pul-i-Talkh a road for wheeled transport would have to be made over a rocky ridge, about 30 feet high and about 150 feet wide, or a bridge built over the stream which is formed by the spring at the end of the ridge. The bank of the stream being marshy, a ford is not practicable unless brushwood were laid down, and there is very little in the vicinity. The remainder of the road is easy and Cl(w)GSB ' V R122 Route No. 23— contd. offers no difficulties, except in very wet weather, when the muddy shores of Lake Nim would be soft for wheels ; continuous ram, however, is rare in the neighbour tiood. This route is regularly used between Jahrum and Shiraz, Bandar ’Abbas and Lar, Lar and Jahrum, occasionally between Lar and Shiraz, and seldom, if ever, between Bandar Abbas and Shiraz. As reards Lar, Bandar ’Abbas is more distant than Lingeh, but the grazing is better and the^road far easier to the former place. Between Lar and Jahrum there is no alternative route, except between Juwun and Jahrum, and the road traversing a succession of fertile plains is regularly used for local traffic. Between Jahrum and Shiraz there is considerable traffic all the year round, which goes almost en tirely by this route, the road via Fasa, or FIruzabad, being much longer and more difficult. Between Bandar Abbas and Shiraz there is practically no traffic, but what there is, appears to adopt this route in preference to that via the Tang-i-Zagh. The depredations occasionally committed on small caravans appear to be the work of the nomads who frequent this route from139 Route No. 29— contd. Birkeh Nub onwards ; the frequency and extent of these raids is* however, absurdly exaggerated by the timorous Persians, and careful enquiry failed to elicit more than two recent authenticat ed cases. Every man in the country traversed appeared to possess arms, mostly breech-loaders, and ammumtion Most_ of the muleteers carried arms between Birkeh Kun and Jahrum, after which there appeared to be little fear of thieves the country traversed being thickly populated. The permanent inhabitants of the country traversed are peaceful ana law-abiding and not at all inclined to raid caravans. # ' . . , Passable throughout for all pack animals, and by infantry and cavalry, the latter with difficulty. The Hormuz valley is left by the difficult Gardan-i-Bazan, after traversing which there are no difficulties as far as Ear. Between Lar and Kumeh the road is again steep, and difficult for camels m places, but rs regularly used bv the latter animals notwithstanding. From Kuideh to Juwun the road is easy and fairly level, a pass presenting some difficu ty beinv traversed between Birij and Binaru. Between Juwun and JahrQm the road is bad in places whichever route be adopted, and camels could not be used via Chah Tiz unless the road was improved. From Jahrum to Shiraz the road is very easy an passable, with some improvement in places, even by artillery. The climate in March and April is much the same as that of the Punjab for the same time of the year, but the nights are much milder. The summer scale of clothing and oedcung should be ample for these months. Rain is seldom experienced at this time of the year and tents would be unnecessary. Date trees flourish from Bandar ? Abbas to Khafr, a sure indication that severe cold is never experienced. Stages 1 to 9, vide Route No. 7. , , fl Stage 10. In March 1907, when this report was written, the spring rams had failed and muleteers along the route reported that the quan tity of water then found was the minimum experienced during the year. Fodder .—Grazing for camels and donkeys is sufficient all the year round along the route ; grazing is at its best in the spring (when the route was traversed) and cannot be relied on as good all the year round. Mules are little used on the route, but from Banan to Shiraz, good grazing could usually be obtained for them in the spring. Elsewhere, and at other season, they w r ould have to be fed on bhusd. Grass for horses wxmld be excessively difficult to obtain at many of the stages ; it is unobtainable from the villages ; Jchasil (green barley) could be extensively used as a substitute from Hormuz onwards, during the spring. Supplies .—Bandar ’Abbas being a seaport in close touch with Karachi, it wxmld, for military purposes, be easiet and cheaper to provide grain and possibly fodder from Karachi. Flour and food-stuff’s are already largely imported from Bombay and local purchase would not be economical. Nomads from Birkeh Nuh onw'ards are always present during winter and spring, and own large flocks, which would probably suffice for three regiments of Indian Infantry moving from day to day. The flocks consist mainly of goats, with a few sheep and a very few cows, from Bandar 5 Abbas to Lar, local supplies, except of cattle are negligi ble, though the resources of towns should suffice to establish victualling depots along the route ; supplies thus provided, one regiment of Indian Infantry could move to Lar without much difficulty. The resources of Lar w T ould probably suffice to victual a brigade with transport for an indefinite period, and also to augment the resources of Dahkuh and Birlz, which are scanty. From Birlz onwards the road traverses a succession of fertile irrigated plains, and by requisitioning supplies at each stage, from the neighbouring villages, two regiments of Indian infantry could be victualled without much difficulty. This is a car van route which has largely fallen into disuse but the portion between Shiraz and Tang-i-Zard is still used by caravans, chiefly of camels or donkeys. Mules, apparently, seldom if ever traverse it. Portions of it might be available for wheeled vehicles. The physical obstcales along this route are less numerous and much le&s formidable than those on the post-road. The passes, with the exception of Tang-i-Bahush, do not present any severe difficulty for infantry or cavalry. The rivers, if native report, which described them in winter as unfordable, be true, might prove more serious. The road may be divided into three sections. The first section, i.e., the first two stages* viz., to Ahram, 25J miles, is almost a dead level and might easily be traversed by wheeled vehicles. The country is open and practicable for all arms. The ground is liable to become heavy after rain, particularly the first stage. The Ahram river, if in flood, might prove troublesome. Between ’Ali Changi and Bunch Gaz the deep fine sand would much impede heavy vehicles. The second section, i.e., stages 3 to 8 inclusive, Ahram to Ixavar Serai, a distance of about ITT miles, is a gradual rise over a country intersected by mountains, valleys and rivers, by a series of passes of which the principal 2d2204 • Route No.- 37 — contd. are the Tang-i-Bahush, Tangab, Gardaneh-i-Siah, and Muk, the highest point being at the top of t e last named pass (about 6,600 feet). None of the passes are as formidable as the fa/tefc-on the post-road ; the Tang-i- Bahush would be distressing for cavalry, and very difficult (Mr. Grahame and Major Brandel are inclined to think ■ impracticable) for artillery, _ _ The third section, i.e.,'from Kavar Serai to Sniraz, about 3o miles, is over fairly level open country. This portion of the road would be practicable for all arms. The last stage is apt to be heavy after rain. The principal obstacles would be fa) The Abram river. The crossing of this a few miles before reaching Ahram (stage 2), and again immediate ly on kaving that place stage 3), might prove river difficult in the winter or early spring if the were in flood. The road is sometimes closed lor a month after rain when the inhabitants_go to Ahram via Chahkutah or Boras] un. The crossing of the river Du Chang, an,, of a larger river about 14| miles east of Bushkan, and of several deep ndlds, might prove troublesome. This march is a most fatiguing one. (d) Stage 6 . This is a long march with a tedious ascent of the Tang Bizan. (e) Stage 7. The Tang Ab pass with the frequ ent crossings of the torrent. (/) Stage 8 . The stiff ascent of the Muk pass. Between the 15th November and the 15th March this tract of country is liable to be occasionally visited by heavy rains. ^ In December 1903 the Ala-ud-Dauleh marching up from Bushire to Shiraz with a large body of men lost four or five of the escort from exposure and cold. In the beginning of December 1904 the Ahram rive m con- sequence of heavy rains rose in flood, carrying away many houses and drowning many people. Wet weather rather than any excessive cold is to be looked20o Route No. 37— contd. ior during the winter months. According to native information the passes are never blocked by snow, but the rivers are often impracticable. In the summer months, of which July and August are hottest, marches would have to be made by night. Ibcder.—The prevalent notion that this route lacks water would appear to be erroneous or grossly exaggerated. The water, as far as Firuzabad (stage o), is generally brackish, though not so much so as to make it unfit for animals. There are a certain number of springs and wells of drinking water sufficient for a regiment. From Firuzabad to Shiraz water is good and plentiful. Leather buckets and ropes for drawing water from the wells, some of which are very deep, would have to be carried. ' ' c . . Fuel.—At the first two stages the supply of fuel, consisting chiefly of brushwood, is scant. From there onward it consists of trees and is fairly plentiful, but not so much so as on the post-road. . ■ Supplies .—Supplies of fodder and forage are, according to native information, more plentiful on this route than on the post-road. ' At the first two stages supplies of all kinds are relatively scantier, but at Tang-i-Zard (stage 3), and from there onwards, plentiful. Firuzabad, with its numerous outlying villages and broad fertile plain, should be able to furnish supplies for a brigade. If previous notice were given, large quantities of supplies might be collected here, and also though to a less extent—in the Khajai and Kavir villages adjacent to the on ward line of march to Shiraz Wheat and barley are harvested from the beginning of May to the beginning of June, according to the elevation. Live-stock from T&ng-i-Zard to Shiraz. Tram port— Donkeys and camels in the proportion of ten to one are employed on this route. Mules are rare. _Of the camels employed a portion belong to Mabiar and Abadeh, their owners seeking to utilise them on this route when the Shiraz-Isfahan route becomes too heavy for them. A portion belong to Jahrum, and are employed to transport opium and other produce from that district, via Firuzabad to Bushire for shipment. A third portion belongs to the Qaraghanlu branch of the Qashgai tribe settled at Firuzabad (ef. stage 5), and, in206 Route No. 37— contd. smaller numbers., in or close to Shiraz, and transports gums and carpets to Bushire, bringing back general merchandize. Gurak ridge, which the road is shown in the map as crossing, is important as offering a posi tion facing S.-W. to a force advancing on Bushire from the E, or S.-E. It commands the low-lying sandy ground towards Bushire, and has a mean elevation of 300 feet above the plain. The right or northern flank is the weakest, and is open to a turning movement under cover of the date plantations. This same ridge should also afford a position facing N.-E. to a force covering Bushire against a force advancing from the E. Its extreme length would necessitate, however, a very strong body of troops to occupy it properly. It would afford some good artillery positions covering the plain towards the main mourn tain ranges. From HARAT-I-KHURREH to ’ALlARAD via arsinjAn. 106 miles. 5 Stages. Authority —Gibbon, 1908. Epitome. The road throughout is an excellent one for pack transport, and very little labour would be required to render it fit for the passage of guns. This route would probably form a good align ment for a railway connecting Kirman with Shiraz via Bahrama- bad and Shahr-i-Babak. The road throughout runs through hilly country, but the hills are more or less detached, and there are no high passes to be crossed. Practically the only work required to render the route passable for wheeled artillery would be the removal of the rocks and stones from the Tang-i-Arsianjan. It may be mention ed, however, that carriages have been known to pass through the Tang even in its present condition. During the winter months the temperature frequently falls below zero and it was understood that the road is frequently affected by falls of snow. Water .—There is plenty of water along the route. It is generally obtained from streams of which there are plenty run ning down from the higher hills on either side of the road. Grazing .—There is plentiful supply of camel-grazing to be obtained en route, generally of low thorn plants. There is also a little grass here and there, and it is thought that during the spring there would probably be a considerable supply. . Fuel .—In some of the ndld beds there is a little tamarisk, but once Kaleh Khan is passed there are large supplies of dwarf oak. Supplies .—Except in the neighbouring of Sarchaun and Arsinjan there would be practically no supplies obtainable. At both these places there would probably be sufficient for a couple of battalions. Not more than one brigade with a proportion of other arms could me the road in one day. For the first four stages the road traverses fiat open country which is liable to become impassable for camels, and difficult for mules, after heavy rain. Then the road rises over 5 main passes which in winter may he Mocked for a week hi a time by snow. The route is passable by infantry and cavalry, but not by field artillery. Animals must move in single file over the passes, and in some place horses must be led. Riding camels have been taken along the road. Loads should ridie high on mules as projecting rooks interfere with them when low. Camels could he used at line of communication transport in dry weather on stages 2, 3, 4, 8 * 9, 12, 13, 14, and on stage 1 in dry weather after a week's work on the road by a battalion of pioneers. To make the whole road passable for laden camels the align ments would have to be altered on the passes, and it is estimated that each pass would occupy a double company of pioneers a week. To enable carts to be used a road would have to be made across the Mashileh (stage 1), and a complete re-alignment of the passes undertaken ; a six months’ task at least for one battalion of pioneers at each pass. There are five main passes, details of which will be found in the Gazetteer, Volume HI. ( 1 ) The Kutal-i-Mahi (stage 5), a very steep ascent of over 1,000 feet by a narrow broken track. The route is passable for all arms including artillery as far as Asupas (3); thence it is only passable by mules as far as the last stage from Shahpur to Kazarun—which is again passable for all arms. The chief difficulties of the road are:— (1) the pass in stage 2 ; this is blocked by snow in winter ; (2) two bad passes in stage 5 ; (3) stage 7 is difficult and is only passable by troops in single file ; (4) the Gudar-i-Tabar Khaneh in stage 11 is imprac ticable for laden mules, and is only passable with difficulty for un laden animals. As there was snow on the pass in June it is probable that the pass is blocked in winter. There is also another dangerous bit of road in this stage, in passing which care must be taken to avoid accidents. Water. —Good and plentiful throughout. Fuel. —Generally abundant, but none at ’Allabad (2) and Maigun (4). Fodder. —Grazing is generally excellent. Authorities. —Markham, 1889 ; Curzon, 1889 ; Stokes, 1904 ; Arbuthnot, 1905; Howe, 1904 ; Chick, 1906; Shakespeare, 1906 ; Christ mas, 1907 ; Blackman, 1907 ; Grahame, Bird wood, and Meade 1908; Capper, 1912 ; Hart, 1913.320 Route No. 65 — contd. Epitome. This is the main caravan route between Shiraz and Isfahan. It runs with comparatively slight difference in altitude across the lofty plateau of Central Persia, the lowest point being 5,000 feet and the highest 8,000 feet. In winter owing to the cold the journey is a formidable undertaking. The caravan and the post road are not identical for the whole of the way the post road often making detours to avoid places unfit for carriage. The following are the chdpar-khanehs in order along the route. They were reported in 1912 as being in ruins. The caravanserais are generally in good repair, capacity one squadron. 1. Shiraz. 13. 2. Baj-gah. 14. 3. Zarghun. 15. 4. Amirbabad. 16. 5. Puzeh-i-Takht-i-Jamshl. 17. 6. Saidun. 18. 7. Quvvamabad. 19. 8. Sa’adatabad, 20. 9. Kulshur. 21. 10. Qadrabad. 22. 11. Hajladad. 22. 12. Dehbld. 24. Khan-i-Khurreh. Surmaq. Abadeh. Shulgistan. Yazd-i-Khast. Ammabad. Maqsud Begi. Qumisheh. Aslab. Mahiar. Chah Ismail Khan. Marq. 25. Isfahan. The road can be used for wheeled artillery and transport except from Quvamabad to Dehbld, which section is avoided by a detour branching off a little beyond the former place, and rejoining the route near Dehbld. Motors have done the journey in 3 days. The first section of the road as far as Quvvamabad is ex tremely rough for wheeled traffic but not impassable, being used by the post carriages. From Zarghun to Quvvamabad during the winter and spring and there is usually deep heavy mud, but for the rest of the year it offers no obstacle. The direct road between Quvvamabad and Dehbld is only fit for mules and camels, and it would require extensive blasting operations to render it fit for wheeled traffic. The alternative route is how ever used by carriages. The remanining section between Dehbld and Isfahan is an excellent road over a gravelly plain with very few bad places. The fords across the Pulvar river become impassable for two or three days at a time in. wet321 r Route No. §5~contd. weather and in winter. The Kul-i-Kush pass is sometimes blocked by snow for two or three months at a time in winter. In this case caravans branch off and go round by Hanashk, rejoining the main road at Khan-i-Khurreh, The physical obstacles are not of very great importance, so far as pack transport is concerned in ordinary seasons, but in connection with wheeled transport the following may benoted : — (i) Stage 1. —Rough and steep gradients over the N’al Shikan and the Gardan-i-Zarghun. These two passes, on account of their stony nature require a large amount of labour to convert them into an easy road for wheels, but at the same time a certain amount of improvement would be effected by the removal of the larger rocks from the track. (ii) Stage 3. —Ford across the Pulvar river, at the end of the Tang-i-Slvand. The ford is bad even for pack animals, but it is avoided by the detour to the E. which leaves the caravan route at Sivand. (iii) Stage 4. —The Tang-i-BulaghI, vide text of route. The road could only be widened here by extensive blasting. (iv) Stage 5. —The road is narrow and bad between miles 5 and 7 ascending over sharp jagged rocks. This m would require a considerable amount of labour to render it a good road. The road is narrow and bad in the descent to Khan-i-Kurgun. From the information at present available it is difficult to esti mate the amount of labour that would be required to improve this bit. Difficulties Nos. (ii), (iii) and (iv) are all avoided by the detour to the E. (vide end of route), but, at the same time, on account of the scantiness of the information, it is impossible to judge of the exact nature of the difficulties to be met with, and the probable amount for labour required to improve it. (r) Stage 6. —The road is narrow and bad in descent to Khan-i-Khurreh. This point would probably require much labour to make it into an easy road. (vi) Stage 10. —The descent into the Yazd-i-Khast ravine is dangerous for carriages or guns. As the banks of the ravine consist of conglomerate rock it would probably not be possible to construct a ramp down Cl(w)GSB - 2 i;322 • Route No. 65'— into it without a large expenditure of labour. This crossing, and the village of Yazd-i-Khast, can be avoided by a detour crosses the ravine 3 to 6 miles to the E. of Yazd-i-Khast, by which Amlnabad is made the halting place, but information does not appear to show that the crossing is so much better than that at Yazd-i-Khast, and it has the disadvantage of making the stage at least 12 miles longer. {vii) Stages 4, 5 and 6 are dangerous, on account of snow in winter months. ISote .—The road is comparatively secure for travellers, if armed, the most insecure, portion being that between Shiraz and Dehbid and from Abad to Maqsud Bagi, when Turkish tribes are about in summer. The winter is fairly mild though on the passes there are often heavy falls of snow between December and March. At times there are heavy falls of rain which affect the passability of the road. In summer, although there is rarely excessive heat the mid-summer months are hot, and it would be inadvisable to march large bodies of troops between the hours of 10 a.m. and 3 p.m. The plain between Zarghun and Pul-i-Khan during the summer months and up to the time of the autumn rains is infested with a small fly knowm as the Khas Mayas. This finds its way into the nostrills of animals and the quietest of animals becomes most voilent in their efforts to get rid of it. At Sivand and Murghab there is invariably fever during the summer and autumn. Animal sickness also prevails and often causes the abandonment of certain portions of the road for a time. Water. —Water good and abundant at stages 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 10, and 12. Water good but limited at stages 6, 9, 11, and 13. ^ Water brackish or of poor quality at stage 14. Up to Dehbid water is obtained on the march from streams. In stages 6, 7 and 10, no water en route ; in stage 11 only at Aminabad ; in stages 9, 12 and 14 probably only obtainable at one or two villages or from the canal in stage 9 : in stage 13 only in the first half of the march ; and in stage 8 no difficulty. Fuel. —From Shiraz to Sivand, particularly over the Marv- dasht, fuel is scarce near the road and timely notice should be necessary to collect it in large quantities at any particular point. Thence to Dehbid a fair amount within easy distance of the road and plentiful in the Tang-i-Bulaghi. The gardens round Surmaq and in the villages on from there to Abadeh would furnish a plentiful supply. Very scarce from Abadeh to Yazd-i-Khast, but at the latter place a very plentiful supply from the gardens. Qumisheh and the villages round obtain wood from the fruit gardens and from the east side O' the mountains separating this portion of the country from the desert. From Qumisheh to Isfahan very scarce.323 Route No. §5—contd. Fodder.—From April to the end of June good grazing for all animals from Shiraz to Dehbld. Camels find their own fodder for eight months and are fed from December to April. The Arab tribesmen find grazing for extensive flocks from May to September. Beyond Dehbid no information. Supplies .—The country depends entirely on its own resources for the ordinary necessaries of life, and the passage of a large force through it, drawing on the country, would in most places result in a famine. At Shiraz and Isfahan supplies for a division for some time. At stages 1, 2, 3, 7, 8, 12, for a regiment, with transport, and perhaps a larger force. At stages 10 and 11, for half a battalion with transport. At stages 4, 5, 6, 9, 13 and 14 for practically nil. The Meshed-Murghab district is a great grain-growing coun try : any year following a good harvest the supply of grain pro curable is abundant, even in mid-winter as transport is never available to take it away. The country round Dehbld is fertile, and although nothing can be procured in Dehbid itself, from the district near, certainly 100,000 maunds of grain would be pro curable. In this district the crops are harvested in the middle of August and further south somewhat earlier. Most of the villages on the route have flocks of sheep and goats of from 50 upwards and generally a few cows. At Murghab a hundred head of cattle might be procured at anytime. The larger towns, such as Shiraz, Abadeh, Qumisheh, and Isfahan could supply a certain amount of groceries. From calculations it is probable that 100,000 men and 25,000 animals moving between Shiraz and Dehbid could feed on the country without drawing on the food supply of the inhabitants. Beyond this towards Isfahan, the country is a poor one. In 1912 it was reported that at most stages supplies were scarce or nil and that cultiva tion was much less than formerly. Caravans consist of mules, camels, and donkeys. At Sivand in the spring 300 miles could be hired for transport and at other times only 50. Up to Dehbid practically none could be hired of bought. After notice at Qumisheh 2,000 donkeys could be obtained and at Mayar 2,000 camels. Donkeys are obtainable in most of the villages in small numbers. In summer muleteers load up soon after midnight and at other times they march during the day. Daily amount of feed for a mule 6 lbs. barley, 20 lbs. Ihusa. A recognized mule-loadRoute No. 65 - contd. is 280 lbs. but it is often much more. Facilities for shoeing practically nil. One or two indifferent smiths at Zarghun and Sivand with little material. Alternative stages .— (a) Fuzeh Zarghun to Kinareh. This route avoids the swampy portion of the Marvdasht plain, but lengthens the journey, and is impassable for wheeled traffic owing to the narrowness of the road in parts. (b) Puhzeh-i-Takht-i-Jamshid to Sivand. The carriage road. (c) Quvvamabad to Dehbid. The carriage road. m Siavnd to ’Allabad. (e) Deh-i-Nau to Meshed-i-Murghab. Avoids a bad pass and has water on it, which the main route has not, otherwise no advantages. (/) Maqsud Begi to Qumisheh. A worse road than the caravan route and impassable except for pack animals. At 2 miles Shiraz is left by the Kuran gate, which is reached from the Consulate by two roads, one through the bazar and the avenue of Deh-i-Buzurg and the other skirting round the city by the Bank garden. The two roads join hear the gate way and near the road to the Bagh-i-Dilkusha. The latter road is hot as broad as the former, but it avoids a high backed river bridge crossed by it, and is ordinarily followed by carriages go ng to the Bagh-i-Nau. The road then runs throuh the Tang-i-Allah-u-Akbar, a narrow ravine with the mountain of Murtaza ’All, on which is the well of the same name, rising abruptly on the right, and the Babakuh on the left or west. The road is led along the side of the latter. The mountains are impracticable except for infantry and mountain batteries. At 3 miles a spring of good w^ater, the Ab-i-Zangi, is passed about half a mile to the east of the road. From the top of the ascent from the gateway the road for about 300 yards crosses uneven sheet rock, and two carriages could hardly pass between the precipitous rock on one side and the low boundary wall of the ravine on the other. At 3| miles a small domed325 Route No. 65— contd. building, the Ambar-i-Chauzi, said to contain water, lies on the left of the road. The road here is frequently broken by w'ater- ooarses, but is passable for wheeled traffic. It then runs between two rocks, and is only 12 feet wide and very bad and stony. At 4| miles the Ab-i-Ruknl crosses the road, which then follows the stream to Gumbad-i-Sabz. Water is excellent and plentiful the whole way. The road now runs across more open country, but rough and stony, with some patches of rock, and passes a small weir diverting a portion of the stream from the right to the left of the road ; here it feeds a small tank from which an irrigation channel runs to the cultivation beyond. The country round here is stony, affording in the autumn a little camel grazing, which becomes more plentiful in the spring. At 7|- miles the entrance of the Barnii pass is reached ; the road hete is very bad. At 8 miles the hills on the right recede slightly affording a small camping ground on the banks of the stream much used by caravans and nomads. This point lies about 800 feet higher than the Kuran gate. The road continues up the pass and at 84 miles reaches Gumbad-i-Sabz, which consists of 20 mad houses, occupied by road lufangchis. No supplies are obtainable here ; the water-supply is perennial, good, and plenti ful from the Ab-i-RuknT. At 9 miles the carriage road branches off to the left. The caravan route keeps straight on, and, cross ing tho kutal just above this point, rejoins the carriage road on the other side near the foot of the mountain. The post road, at 9| miles, running between the spurs from the mountains on either side, narrows to 15 feet, but opens out again at once, and, turning to the right, climbs the Gardan-i-Na’l Shikan, or Bamfo with an average slope of 4 or 5. The gardan is reached at 9§ miles, about 300 feet higher than the camping-ground at Gum bad-i-Sabz. The slope of the first part of the descent is 8, steepening to 10 or about 15 yards. The road follws a nald between the mountains, and is just passable for wheels; gun's would have to be man-handled down. At 10 miles the telegraph again crosses the road. At 10| miles the road turns to the left and fesUmes its original direction, having descended 325 feet in326 Route No. §5—-canid. 1,000 yards, and passes the caravanserai of Bagah. This is apost stage for carriages and post fourgons ; it is generally called 12 miles from Shiraz. The caravanserai is a stone and cement building lined inside with burnt bricks, blocking the pass, and affording a strong defensive post except against guns. Water is obtainable from a small spring about 18 inches wide by a few inches deep ; it is sweet and clear, and is collected into a tank some 11 feet square, for irrigation purposes ; animals can be watered at the tank. The road now runs across the Bajgah plain, in wdiich there is a little cultivation and sparse grazing: in winter the going here is very muddy aid heavy. At 12 miles the ascent of the Kutal-i-Zarghun com mences. (Blackman says he believes that the proper name of the pass is the Gardaneh-i-Ab Barik). The average slope of the ascent is from 4 to 5. The top is reached at 12|- miles. The descent is very rough and bad but is fit for wheeled transport. For the first 1,300 yards the average fall is one in 15, but the slope is not constant, and is in many places very steep. Car riages have the choice of two roads, which divide at the top of the pass, and joins again in the valley at the foot of the moun tain. The road gradually descending continues down the valley to 13 f miles ; here the valley is about a half mile wide, but opens out to the S.-E. Twx> hundred yards further on the stream emerges from the kdriz and runs down the valley : its banks are low and animals can be watered without any difficulty. The road now undulates over spurs from the hills on the left, the ground on the right falling away to the water course of the valley. At 17J miles the village of Dudak is passed about one mile on the right. At 19f miles a road to the left runs direct to the Puzeh Zarghun, avoiding the village of that name and shortening the dis tance to the Marvdasht plain by one mile. Leaving Zarghun 391 m. the road runs N.- W. for one mile, with the mountains rising abruptly on the right, and cultivation on the left, to the Puzeh-i-Zarghun, where it enters the Marvdasht plain. At the Puzeh is a well of good perennial water and a qdvedtkhdneh. The short cut from the last stage which avoids Zarghun rejoins the post road here. At the Puzeh the road bifurcates. One road follows the line of the mountains to the Band Amir, where it crosses the river of that name, vide alternative stage {a). The other, which is the post road, runs N.-E. across the Marvdasht plain to the bridge of Pul-i-Khan. The former road is used by caravans in winter when the plain to the S. of the river is swampy in places. The post road runs across the Marvdasht plain. The mountains turn to the N.-E. and bound the plain on that side. Cultivation continues on both sides of the road for a few hundred yards, when the road again bifurcates. The right hand track, which is used in dry weather, cuts off a considerable corner. The main road continues on until it reaches the first of a series of eight causeways, II feet broad, and in bad repair, where it bears to the right. The causeway is known as the Pul-i-Khurdeh. By these causeways the road is led across the marshy ground which is formed here by rain328 Route No. 65—confcZ. in wet weather; they are in a wretchedly dilapidated state. The two tracks join each other on approaching the bridge of Pul-i-Khan which is reached at miles. About a hundred yards before reaching the bridge, the road turns sharp to the left round the end of a rocky ridge which here rises from the plain, and runs N.-W. parallel to the river, commanding the bridge and its approaches from either side. The approach to the bridge between the river and the ridge is over boulders and bare rocks, and at right angles to it. The roadway of the bridge is stone paved and only 12| feet wide. The bridge has a very steep pitch up to and down from the crown, the slope from the right bank being 9 and that down to the left bank 12. Much delay to troops and transport would have to be allowed for as certain to occur here. The bridge is of stone with three arches, the curves of which are of brick ; height of central one above normal flow 16 feet. The pa rapet is three feet high. The river, though elsewhere slug gish, here runs strongly. The fall from the Puzeh Zarghun to the river bank is only 75 feet. Leaving the bridge the road runs through a cutting for 250 yards, on the left of which the Pulvar river flows, at this point slowly, 25 feet wide with banks 20 feet high. The Pulvar river, which joins the Band-i-Amir above the bridge, bends in towards the road here. From cutting the road runs across the plain, which, on this side of the river, is much cultivated, and intersected with numerous irrigation channels. At 11 miles reach Amlrabad, which is a changing post for horses. The caravan track leaves Amirabad about 1J miles to the left, and continues N.-E. to 17-J miles, where a branch road runs to the village of Kinareh 1J miles distant. This village is generally used as a halting place by travellers. The post waggons, however, usually follow the main road to the chdpdrkhdneh at Puzeh-Takht-i-Jamshld. The road continues over the level plain and crosses the deep irrigation canal which supplies Kinareh with water by a wood and mud bridge, unfit for heavy traffic. It is made of six 15-feet poplar poles covered with reeds and mud. Kinareh and ’Aliabad are practically one village, about 300 mud houses. There is a walled garden to the west in which is a bald Jchaneh. Five hundred goats ; 60 cws. Donkeys 500. The average length of the stage from the previous reports is 20 miles. S. of the Band-i-Amir river the plain also becomes marshy in wet weather, and impassable for traffic except by the causevmys. The flood may possibly take 5 or 6 days to subside during which time the road is impassable. Troops could move across the plain anywhere in dry weather, but N. of the river the numerous irrigation channels would compel artillery and wheeled transport to move by the road. Goats 200, cows 100. Rations for a brigadie would be procurable. Water from a phenomenal spring rising358 Route No. 65— contd. at Bannu the supply of which is good and inexhaustible. There are three mills within half a mile of the village, which can grind 100 maunds of flour each in a day. From Meshed-i-Murghab the road runs to and crosses to Bannu stream. It then ascends and descends over hilly country to the place where this pheno menal spring rises. The road to the junction of the routes from here is stony, and in two places very bad indeed. Artillery would have to leave the road and go across country. At the first, the top of the ascent after leaving the spring, a road would have to be made ; at the second, by keeping to the water-course on the right of the road, guns might be got round the bad place. The road runs from village down the valley and is 227J m. very bad. It is much enclosed between garden walls, and crosses cultivation intersected by irrigation channels. The route strikes off from the post road at Maqsud Begi and continues to run for a short distance further to the west, and then about parallel to that road. It first passes under the N. wall of Maqsud Begi and then runs across irrigated cultivation, and between walled gardens to Khasurah, where spade work would be necessary to make it fit for wheeled traffic. It then continues, first between walls and then over cultivation, to Dahak, round two sides of which it runs ; here again spade work would be required to fit it for wheeled traffic. Continuing it passes Massini on the right. From here it again requires spade work in many places, such as at the irrigation channels, to make it good for traffic. Another walled village is then passed. Afterwards the road becomes very narrow and has at first a wall on the right, being afterwards sunk between the surrounding cultivation. After crossing a stony piece of open ground it fords an irrigation channel which work a mill passed on the right. The road is here fair, with no359 Route No. 65 — contd . cultivation on the left. The walls of the garden of Sular next con fine the road, and the village of that name is reached surrounded by gardens. From here the road runs to Maran, being in places very bad, through enclosed country where spade work again could be necessary or guns would have to be man-handled. The walls of the cultivation of Quvvamabad are to be seen from here, across the ndld which runs between this and the post-road. The next section of the road is much broken by the banked irrigation channels which cross it: traffic would be difficult, if not impos sible, unless they wore cleared away. The village of Ziarat is reached through country which is still much enclosed, Dalandun having first been passed. On leaving the former a broad ndld is crossed, in which is cultivation. The road then runs sunk between the cultivation on either side, and here improves. The gardens and village of Vasbab are then reached and the road runs from there, first between walls, and then over cultivation, to the junction with the post-road a little over three-quarters of a mile from Qumisheh. From the foot of the gorge the track runs easterly across a barren plain, passing a few isolated hills at first, to Qalu Shur, 17 miles. Qalu Shur is a small walled village with stone-built caravan serai in very good condition. Camping ground. —Un] imited. Water .—Good and abundant from kdriz and irrigation chan nels. Supplies. —Nil. The track passes between the village and caravansarai and continues N.-W. across a flat open plain, subject to inundation. At the 20th mile the track commences a slight ascent over shaley surface and at the 22nd mile commences to cross the deep undu lating ridge that covers the approach to Isfahan. Here a branch tract, suitable for pack transport, branches off to the bridge of Ali Verdi. The ridge, which is a very important tactical feature, can be crossed by all arms, including wheeled artillery everywhere but wheeled trans port should be confined to the track. At the 27th mile the track enters the graveyard and continues through it to the bridge of Khaju, 27| miles. A broad boulevard leads from the bridge. ROUTE No. 66. From SHIRAZ to QUMISHEH, via FATHABAD, KUSHK-X -Z ARD, QISHLAQ, ISFAJRJAN anc SULAR. 222^ miles. 12 stages. Authorities. —Webb, Grahame, Birdwoocl, Meade, 1908. Epitome. The route as far as Kushk-i-Zard is a caravan route for mules and camels during the summer months, April to September, and is used by the tribesmen during their migrations in spring and autumn. For the last two years caravan traffic over this route has much decreased owing to the insecurity prevalent thereon. The surveyor Sultan Muhammad, in February 1908, reports the number of horses in a good many villages to be from thirty to fifty more than the number given in this route. The usual caravan stages are :— 1. Zarghum 7. Kushk-i-Zard. 2. Fathabad. 8. Baba Shaikh Ahmad. 3. Main. 9. Qishlaq. 4. Imamzadeh-i-Ismail. 10. Hinijan. 5. Rlza Abad. 11. Sular. 6. Asupas. 12. Qumisheh. The road may be conveniently divided into four sections : 1. Shiraz to Hashimabad. See stage 3. About 48| miles. 2. Hashimabad to Kushki-i-Zard. Stages 3 to 7. About 74^ miles. 3. Kushk-i-Zard to Hinijan. Stages 7 to 10. About 71361 Route No. Q6—contd. 4. Hinijan to Qumisheh. Stage 12. About 15 miles. Section i, Shiraz to Hashimdbdd* This section presents no difficulties of any kind and is open for wheeled traffic throughout the year. It should^ however, be noted that the portion of the road on this section from the 2nd to 3rd mile of stage 2 (Zarghun-Fathabad), covered by the raised causeway known as Pul-i-Khurdeh and the surrounding swampy ground, frequently presents considerable difficulty for wheeled traffic and even, in abnormal seasons, for the passage of pack animals between the months of November and April. Section 2, Hdshimdbdd to Kushk-i-Zard. This section presents exceptional difficulties at certain parts,. .viz .— (а) The crossing of the river Khaneh Kirgan on approach ing Main from the south. See stage 2. (б) The Imam zade h - i - Is mail Pass. (e) The swampy ground at the approach to Kushk-i-Zard from Asupas. Section 3. Kusbk-i-Zard to Hinijdn. The difficulties in this section arise rather from lack of sup plies and from the absence of any clearly defined track or land marks over a large tract of almost entirely uninhabited upland. Patches of treacheroup^swampy ground which occur unexpectedly on portions of this section would also be the cause of additional difficulties. Section 4, Hinijdn to Qumisheh. This is a short section of about 15 miles where the presence of a swift mountain stream immediately bordering and at times encroaching on the first four miles of the track which here passes down a narrow ravine, presents obvious difficulties even in the summer months. Note .—It should be particularly noted that between Asupas on section 2 and Hinian on section 3 show, attaining at times a depth of one zar . 1 ®» according to native report, prevalent during the three winter months, i.e, BeCe The e approach'toThe Irish bridge across the river Khaneh Kirgan a few railes south ol Main, would have to be made practicable for wheeled traffic by P^eers. The chief feature remarked between April 27th to Ma> 12th was the extremes of temperature in the twenty-four hours. The inhabitants at ^ushk-^£ard Isfarian and Qumisheh made ment on of excessive rams m the late autumn, m particular the excessive rainfall of the Matter part of December 1 ^ caused disastrous floods. At Asupas local report says that mosquito^ abound and fever is prevalent during the summer and autumn, also a hore^^ease known W SinehV'irw (pneumonia). The inhabitants added that the winters were so severe that it was impossible to keep sheep with profit.362 Route No. 66-— contd. Water .—Water is abundant all the year round throughout ; rivers, springs, wells, qanats, reservoirs. Fud. —Brushwood, e.g., camel-thorn, for fuel was abund- smt. Fuel from trees only obtainable in any quantity at certain stages. Fodder.—Gracing for camels and mules and horses plenti- ul throughout the seasons when the road is available. The presence of the noxious plant, euphorbia, was noted at Qishlaq. Supplies .—Grain supplies over the major portion of the road would present considerable difficulties. Live-stock is abundant at all times, more particularly in spring and autumn when the tribes are on the march. In cases of emergency a mounted force not exceeding 1,500 men and horses could be pushed through by this route, procuring their own supplies. It would be difficult or even impossible to send infantry by this route relying on the local supplies, which at certain stages^ e.g. y Baba Shaikh Ahmad, stage 8, and Qishlaq, stage 9, are nil. Kushk-i-Zard or the neighbouring village of Shahr Mian, see stage 8, Asupas and Hinijan appeared to be the most promising centers for collecting supplies but it was impossible to gauge the amount of supplies from native information. Wheat and barley are harvested from mid June to mid July according to altitude. Caravans using this route are composed of camels or mules. Donkeys, ponies and cows are used by the tribesmen. According to native information mule caravans using this route (i.e., Kushk-i-Zard or Yazd-i-Khast) vary from 100 to 2,000 mules, and camel caravans from 10 to 500 camels. The hire of mules varies greatly, but latterly has fluctuated from rupees 24 to 30 (Tcrans 80 to 100) from Shiraz to Isfahan. Muleteers usually shoe their own animals. No transport under ordinary circumstances available along this road. The usual allowance of forage given by muleteers to their mules is two Shiraz! maunds (i.e., 14*6 lbs.) of straw and 2J ShirazI maunds of barley (i.e., 18'2 lbs.). The Marvdasht plain here forms a rectangle bounded on the S. by low bluffs, at the foot of which flows the river Pulvar, westward, by three great isolated masses of rock—Kuh-i-Sharaq, Kaleh Shikasteh and Mian Kaleh which rise like Titanic citadels out of the plain northward by the Kuh-i-Gharmabad rising above to Naqsh- i-Rustam. The fourth side is cut by the postal road to Puzeh. The eastern portion of this rectangle is copiously watered by the river Sivand and by artificial water channels drawn from it. Shortly afterwards two paths join the track, one from Behbid, a village about 3 miles N.-N.-E., the other from Ahmadabad or ’Imadabad, and Hasanabad, villages lying respectively about 2 miles and 1 mile N.-W. At about 9 miles 2 furlongs the road, now trending N.-W., crosses a small streamlet and at 10 miles again strikes the main channels of the Sivand river, apparently an artificial channel, from about 18 to 20 yards broad with level banks, at a point where it is traversed by an Irish bridge partially ruined but practicable. At 9 miles 3 furlongs crossing another branch of the river by a small stone bridge the road deflects towards N.-N.-E. and, funning between the river on the E. and artificial water channel on the W., reaches at 12 miles 4 furlongs the village of Fat ha bad ; about 200 houses. From Bani Yaki two roads run to Hashimabad, the more easterly hugging the base of the bluffs already mention ed all the way up the valley, the other moving almost parallel to and about 2 furlongs W. of it. Just beyond Hashimabad the river Kur, locally styled the Qain Piran river, which here runs parallel to and about 6 furlongs W. of the road, becomes visible. Both banks are very high and steep. Breadth of stream about 30 yards. The inhabitants assert that there is no means of crossing it here. The road continues to move up the valley between the river, 200 to 500 yards to the W., and the bluffs rising immediately on the E. Several springlets trickle down at intervals from the high bank E. across the road and a streamlet is carried along a channel artificially cut in the rock. About 20 miles another rocky spur strikes from the E. into the road, which is further cut up at this point by several small watercourses, springs and scattered boulders. Attached to this is a walled and castel lated mud village said to contain about 120 houses, of which only half, according to native report, are now inhabited, recent rains having wrought havoc in the village. The inhabitants are of Ilidt origin. Camping ground .—For a brigade. Water .—Plentiful Supplies. —Nil. 8 BABA SHAIKH 23 m. General direction — AHMAD- N.-W. The cara- 142^ m. 8,900’. van road, which passes Kushk-i-Zard some 400 yards to the W. of it, runs to Piil-i- Shikan, for the first six miles in a direction slightly W. of N., ^crossing several small water-courses, some dry shallow ndlds and two patches of marshland. Immediately after quitting the latter of these it deflects to slightly E. of N. and continues thus till at 10 miles 4 furlongs it strikes the river at a spot known as Pul-i-Shikan. The river itself is locally known as the Shikan and a ruined village standing on the N. bank of the river about half a mile distant from this spot bears the same name. The bridge exists in name only. The river, which is here about 10 to 12 yards wide, is crossed diagonally by a ford, the water being about 3 feet deep, at the deepest point, in May. From Pul-i-Shikan two routes lead to Qishlaq, the one, the usual caravan road which continues in almost the same direction as the road !Route No. 86— contd. from Knsbi-i-Zard to the ford, the other, a track in many places quite undefined, only known to and used by the tribesmen. Moving N. W. up the valley, which is here about 4 to 5 miles broad, it strikes the river. Shaikhan at about 13 miles 5 furlongs and during the rest of its course to Baba Shaikh Ahmad runs more or less parallel to this river, which varies in breadth from 10 to 20 yards and in places feeds some patches of cornland, or spreads itself out over marshland which makes it necessary to be cautious. At about 15 miles the valley widening out discloses in the dis tance to the W. the magnificent Damneh range covered with perpetual snow. At about 17 miles a few patches of barley appear and a little mud homestead, said to be inhabited by 3 or 4 families only, is sighted about 1| miles off the road to the W. The road here skirts a series of hummocks, offshoots of the mountains which bound the plain on the E. At about 19 mites a ruined building, Kaleh Qambar Agha, with a cemetery, stands by the roadside on the E. From about this point the ascent of the road, very gradual throughout its whole course, becomes slightly more marked and the patches of the marshland more extensive, making the approach to the Imamzadeh somewhat treacherous. At about 22 miles the Imdmzddeh is reached, a lonely little shrine roughly built of unhewn stone, tapped by a bluish dome. Some tombstones are scattered immediately round the Imdmzddek and there is a small cemetery hard by In front of the Imdmzddeh is a deep spring with a leather bucket and a rope* The place is intensely lonely; there is not even a guardian to the shrine.
