Shaikh Ahmad at 340 degrees the track runs towards a well-defined gap in the range of mountains which bound the plain on the N.-W. A con spicuous conical hill towards the western extremity of this range, some 3 miles from the track, is pointed out as the source of the river Shikan and designated Qabristan-i-Kaha. At 1 mile 2 furlongs the river is crossed and the ground begins to rise slightly. The distant snow-covered peaks of the * Kuh-i-Damneh reveal373 Route No. 66— contd. themselves on the W. At about 6 miles 3 furlongs the middle of the gap (about one furlong wide) is reached. A spring trickles across the road from the rocks on the E. From 6 miles 4 furlongs to 9 miles the track, deflecting slightly more to the W. and ascending to a height of 9,000 feet, traverses an amphitheatre about 2 miles wide down which flows a streamlet fed by numer ous springs. Here and there the water is diverted to patches of wheat, sowings of Qashqals. At 8 miles a few hundred yards W. of the road are the remains of a cemetery and of some build ings standing on slight rise above patch of barely and wheat watered by adjacent springs. The spot, apparently a deserted or half-deserted Qashqai settlement, was variously designated by the guides as Harvan or Arran. At 11 miles the track crosses a stream and moving N. runs over a low ridge rising gradually to 9,500' at about 12 miles. Then deflecting slightly, more to the W., it descends very gradually along the top of a projecting spur of a hill with a nala on both sides. About 13 miles 4 furlongs it drops down and loses itself in the western and broader of these two ndlds at a point close to where these two ndlds unite. Just before this drop an extensive patch of verdure, representing Qishlaq, becomes visible northward beyond the windings of the ndld. This might perhaps be reached more quickly and more easily by following the ndld. The track, however, lost for 200 or 300 yards in the bottom of the ndld, becomes clearly discernible again on the W. bank of this, a little further N. Emerging from the ndld it runs N.-N.-W. over undulating ground traversed by several deep ndlds in rapid succession. Dropping at about 17 miles into a grass-clad ravine at a spot known as Deh Kahid, marked by three large willow trees and the extensive ruins of a kaleh (on the W.), it runs along the western side of the ravine, which is about 2 to 6 furlongs wide, passing at 21 miles 6 furlongs another ruined kaleh on the W., with a small Imdmzddeh adjacent to Plr-i-Daud. Here patches of cultivation, fed by the stream which flows down the ravine (the ground in places is treacherous), denote the approach of Qishlaq, which is reached at 23 miles. There is no village,—only the remains of a kaleh too ruined to afford any shelter to man or beast. Camping ground.—JAmited and bad. Water. —Abundant. Fuel.- —Brushwood. The caravan 190 1 m. r°ad, passing W. of ruined fort of Qishlao, begins at once to ascend gradually In aTw. direction and continues to do so for about 9| miles, traversing undulating ground formed by the spurs of the mountains which run immediately to the W. of the road. The track is in places so ill-defined as to render a guide absolutely -necessary. The soil, loose sand and gravel, overgrown with tufts of aromatic brushwood, is impregnated with moisture which reveals itself ever here and there in the form of a hill, running across the road, or a patch of soft treacherous ground. At the fifth mile a track traversing the road at right angles, connects Hanna on the W. with Yazd-i-Khast on the E., the latter being, according to native information, 3 farsakhs from this point. Between the 9th and 10th miles high mountains bound the horizon, the Kuh-i-’AlI Jan on the N.-W., the Kuh-i-Dupalang range to the N.-E. The road, still passing over undulating, ground, descends at first gradually (for about H miles), then abruptly for a mile through a steep ndla, a drop of about 400 feet, to a broad valley divided longitudinally by a streamlet feeding patches of cornland. Then rising again gradually it strikes at about 17 miles 4 furlongs the main caravan road run ning, according to native information, from Shiraz vid Kam Elruz, Dizzeh Kurd and Hanna through Hinijan to Qumisheh. This road is at this point and as far as the 22nd mile well trodden and suitable for wheeled traffic. The two routes unite and the road continues to rise for about another mile attaining an atlitude of about 9,400 feet, then descending gradually for another 11 miles strikes across another partially cultivated plain at the N. end of which two ruined enclosures representating the deserted village and caravanserai of Mash, are passed at 21 miles on the W. Almost immediately after passing this point the road makes an abrupt change of direction running N.-E. to Hinijan. At 21 miles 7 furlongs a streamlet flowing with a velocity of about 12 miles an hour from theW. is crossed by bridge (of rough stones and mud supported by 3 arches, breadth of roadway 4 feet) in bad repair. At this point and for the rest of the stage the road is impassable for wheeled traffic. From here to Hinijan the road and the stream run almost parallel to one another. Patches of cultivation begin to appear. At about 23 miles there is a spring375 Boute No. 66— contih in a meadow by the E. side of the road. At 23 miles 4 furlongs a little grove of trees on the W. of the road marks a zldrat-gdh or place of pilgrimage. Here the village of Hinijan suddenly comes in sight, an isolated hillock crowned with two khalehs, covered with tiers of houses and girt about with tall poplars. At 23 miles 6 furlongs a mill is passed about 4 furlongs E. of the road. Carefully willed fruit gardens on the hillsides, which here close in, form a distinctive feature of the place. At about 24 miles 2 furlongs the road crosses a streamlet, over which a mill is built, and bifurcates, the E. branch leading to the lower part of the village, the W. to the rising ground. Hinijan or Hinjan is a remarkably flourishing village. About 250 families ; 57 head of cattle ; 4 or 5 mills. Camping ground. —W. and S. of a newly constructed mud enclosure at the N. end of the village, uneven and stony. No available camping ground near river owing to much cultivation. Water. —Good. For the first 4 miles 21 If m. the road runs parallel with the Isfarjan river, here a rapid streamlet 5 to 6 yards broad, in a N.-W. direction down a ravine which in places is so narrow as just to leave room for the river and a narrow track, in others widens out into patches of cultivated land and little orchards. On the E. run the Kuh-i-Palang, on the W., the Kuh-i-Vasm. At 1 mile 4 furlongs the stream is crossed W. to E. by a rough stone bridge and recrossed a mile lower down by a bridge of stone and wood. Shortly after two mills (one ruined) are passed on the W. side of the road between it and the river. At 3 miles 6 furlongs remains of a land are visible on both sides of the stream. A little beyond this point the ravine begins to open out and the village of Isfarjan, said to contain 600 families, embedded in orchards and gardens, is traversed, the main por tion of the village being on the E. of the road. From Isfarjan a track leads to Daulatabad and Yazd-i-Khast. (Route No. 65, stage 10.) From Isfarjan Qumisheh may be reached by two routes, viz., Ta,rghto and Talkhun or bySular emd Mehiar. At 15 miles 4 furlongs the monotony Of the plain is broken by a mamelon of rock rising about 800 feet abruptly out of it on the immediate V/. of, and commanding, the road. Just before reaching this mamelon a path branching off eastward leads to the little village of Bang. The main caravan road running for about two miles under this mamelon then deflects slightly more towards the E. and at about 200 miles reachers Sular. Sular, a village of about 80 houses, s tanning on the E. of the road among cornlands and fruit gardens, is partially walled. Rifles said to number 30. Camping xjround. —Unlimited. Water. —Abundant. Authorities and dates. —Jones, 1857 ; Schindler, 1880; Wells, 1881 ; McGowan, 1895 ; Hopkins, 1903; Gabriel, 1905; Graham, 1906; Surveyor Sultan Muhammad, 1910 ; Chick, 191 • ; Epitome. As far as Behbehan (st±ge 3) the route is the direct and usual one used to connect Behbehan with the coast. Behbe han is the main collecting and distributing centre for this part of the country. The remainder is the caravan route on to Shiraz, but is not much used at the present time (1911) owing to the unsafeness of the road. Mule and donkey transport is used principally throughout the route, and almost exclusively on the maritime plain. The road for the greater partis a track over rough and hilly country, which is broken up by ravines. As a rule it is only fit for pack transport; but between the Chal-i-Mureh (stage 7) and the end of the Fehlian or Palian plain (about 20 miles), and from ’Aliabad (stage 9) to Shlrlz (about 40 miles) it is passable for wheeled traffic. In the summer months the heat in the earlier stages would probably be excessive. The winters are mild in the maritime plain; snow falls near Shiraz. The physical obstacles are not formidable. They are:—- (а) Stage 7. —The steep ascent from the Chal-i-Mureh. Gradient—— (б) Stage 7. —The projecting spur of rock between Tall-i- Surneh and Deh Nau. This would require blasting. (c) Stage 8 .'—The steep descent of the Tang-i-Garru to Pu- i-Murd. Gradient— T 1 g (d) Stage 8 .—The crossing of the river at Pul-i-Murd might present difficulties in the spring ; the existing bridge might easily be rendered passable. (e) Stage 9. —The ascent from Pul-i-Murd to the’Aliabad plateau ; 3 stages.380 Route No. 67 — contd. Wafer.—Is abundant and good from numerous streams. Leather buckets and ropes are necessary in places. Fuel.—Except at Talaspid fuel is plentiful throughout the route from oaks and bushes. Supplies. —At some of the larger villages and in the valleys a certain amount of grain might be collected. Large num bers of flocks and herds are owned by the inhabitants of the district, of whom great numbers are nomads. Zaidan, Behbehan, Talaspid and Guyum appear to be the best centres for collecting supplies. Grazing.—Grazing is plentiful in the spring and summer months. . . „ Mules and donkeys seem to be used principally, and pro bably some 300 could be collected in the Behbehan district. Camels are seldom if ever used. Transport animals are scarce in the Mamassani village. Alternative routes. —(A) from Talaspid (stage 7) to Kazarun, thence wd route 59 to Shiraz. Turning S. the 158 1 m. road crosses the Fehlian, river which is 40 yards wide and 1J' deep -with a shingly bed ; and then follows its left bank, leaving Fehlian village 2 miles to the S. at the foot of the mountains. At 24 miles pass Kaleh Sarkari (or Maliki) and at 4 miles Deh Shah Hussaini. The route sweeps round the hi. side of the Fehlian valley and at 5 miles pass the Imamzadeh of Shah Jehan Ahmad and the adjoining village of Aregan. At about 64 miles the track crosses a rocky spur on the other side of which an extensive cultivated plain opens out on both sides of the Fehlian river, along the right bank of which the route runs. Above the left bank rises the Kaleh Safid. A valley running X. and S. admits a tributary stream (said to be the river Joujak ?) which sweeps down to the main stream in an “ S ” shaped curve. At 12 miles the route crosses to the left bank by a ford 30 yards below a weir which diverts a considerable volume of water to an adjoining expanse of cultivation, known as the Du-dank ; and about 1 mile further recrosses to the right bank. For the next 2 miles the track is bad and rocky ; and ascends to a considerable height passing a sul phur spring. Descending again, at 16 miles it crosses to the left bank where a tributary stream flows in ; and f mile further on recrosses to the right bank, which it follows for J mile. Here it leaves the river and, passing a small spring at 17 | miles, ascends abruptly about 400 feet over rocky ground and then descends though the Tang-i-Garrau (gradient \j) to Pul-i-Murd, passing at 184 miies a spring called the Chashmeh-i-Garrau. A short distance below Pul-i-Murd the Rud-i-Shul joins the river, which henceforth is known (according to local information) as the river Khas. At Pul-i-Murd is a bridge of solid stone and mortar* formerly of five arches ; the main arch has disappeared, leaving a gap of 25 yards through which the stream, locally known as Ab-i-Laleh, flows with considerable force, from north to S. ; three arches remain on the east side and one on the W. These support a road 12' broad with a parapet of stone and mortar 2' high. On the other side of the ridge it descends abruptly to the right bank of a small stream flowing m a deep gorge. The road ascends this gorge for about 10 miles in the course of which it rises about 3,000 feet; this portion of the route in its present condition (1910) is entirely unfit for wheeled transport. At 2J miles the track crosses to the left bank. '■ The village of Deh Eamir is left about 1| miles to the S. ; 6 houses some sheep and goats; cultivation, a little wheat. About here there is plenty of grass and timber ; and the hills are covered with small oaks. At miles pass a mill known as Asiab-i- balar, and, continuing along the left bank of the stream, the track rises and descends abruptly over very bad ground strewn with rocks. This rise is known as Tang-i-Duktar Pari (the maiden’s leap). At 9 miles the track crosses to the right bank and passes the remains of two stone buildings known as the Caravanserai-i- Badarag. After passing this, the track crosses to the left bank and soon after recrosses to the right. About 9| miles a spring is reached, and 3 miles further on another spring of good water, known as the Chashmeh-i-Chehar Qash, oozes up from a bed of reeds. These two springs form the stream which flows with some force down the valley in a stony channel half hidden by a dense growth of sedge reeds and willows. From this point to the Icutal, which is reached at 144 miles, there is no water in the gorge and the track is 15 broad. From this point the road descends through a wooded valley with fine oak trees, known as the Niwa valley; passes a small spring a 15|- miles ; and then, traversing undulating uncutlivated ground, at 19 miles crosses a deep rial a with a streamlet running N. and S. From here a road branches off S.-W. and is reported to lead to SaranjilakRoute No. 67-— contd. At 91 miles reach ’Allabad, a half ruined and deserted fort on a mound, past which a stream flows. The ’Ahabad plateau, abounding wit h water, afforos a camping ground for Mamaosani., who possess some sheep and goats and from whom scanty sup plies might be obtained. The road now traverses undulating hills and at 211 miles crosses a ndld with a small stream flowing from N.-W. to S.-E. At 22 miles the ’Allabad plateau is left, and a gradual descent of 21- miles through oak forest to the pu] i Duzakh commences, passing at 24 miles a ruined caravan serai on the N. of the track. The Pul-i-Diizakh is solidly built of masonry, one arch, 11 yards long by 5 wide, parapet about 3' high It spans a gorge 100' deep and 15' wide, at the bottom of which is a torrent, 1' deep with a rocky bed. The approaches to the bridge on both sides are bad and encumbered with rocks. The route ascends half a mile to an oak covered ridge ; and desends on the other side to Tang-i-Rudian at 26 miles. Here is a river 40 yards wide, \V deep, with a swift current, running in a S andy bed parallel to' the Pul-i-Duzakh river, but on a level some 300'higher. Route No. 64 connects here. _ 10 GUYUM • • 28 m. General direction b.-R. The road rises some 2^2 m 400' over a bare ridge ; arid at If miles crosses 2 small streams which join about | mile S of the road. At 2 miles cross at right angles a broad track runnino- from Kazarun northwards ; route No. 58. At 2J miles cross a small ndld ; thence across a plain about 4 miles wide witn numerous springs. At 6| miles a road branches off N. -NW. to Ardakan, passing at 4 miles the village of Dahm and an adjacent, imdmzddeh. The road ascends slightly between 2 conical hills At 9 miles reach Sangar situated at the foot of the mils ; -0 houses ; extensive cultivation round the village ; plenty of sheep and goats ; water from a small qandt; fuel scarce. 1 he road gradually ascends the valley which becomes narrower as Hhul is reached at 13 miles. This is a small village with a square stone tower ; two watering tanks on the E. of the road ; camping ground for one brigade ; a few large trees. At 13£- miles a qanat by the road side ; thence up a steep ascent by a stony track, between vineyards, for 11; miles to the top of the Tang-i-fehulp, elevation 7,200'. This village is situated in the middle of a plain about 2 J- miles wide by 3 long* one qanat, but water scarce ; cultivation round village scanty • vineyards on hill sides to the E. The road crosses the dry bed of a stream, and continues down the valley, which again narrows at 24| miles; from here it descends a little and at 26 miles crosses a stream about 80 yards broad. Four miles from the road the prosperous village of Qalat lies at the foot of the Kuh-i-Shurk-i- Qalat, screened from the road by low hills; abundant water; rich vineyards ; no wheat, nor barley. The road now crosses an almost level plain, 2| miles wide, with high hills on either side. At 28 miles reach Guyum ; a large village enclosed by a high mud wall with towers ; extensive wheat cultivation and vineyards ; large flocks of sheep and goats. % ■ y * > ^ Water. —Water from 2 qanats, the Ab-i-Qalat and the Ab-i- Qavamabad, both having their origin in the Kuh-i-BarafL Supplies. The road tra- m ; verses low hills ; and at 2 miles passes through a gap in the hills near which is an db-ambdr ; here a road branches N.-E. towards the Bizah dist rict. At 2f miles the small walled village of Da Kuhak on a mound, on the W. of the road and immediately opposite an old caravanserai. Half a mile further on is a walled garden and mill Asiab-i-Bazam, and also the large fortified village of Qasr-i- Qumisheh, in the vicinity of which wheat and barlev are cul tivated on the plain, vines and melons on the lower slopes of the mountains. Soon after passing this village several tracks lead E.-S.- E. over the plain to the village Khushk-i-Bichah, about 2 miles distant, whence a good level track running eastward along a well-watered valley reaches in 4 miles Gumbad-i-Sabz,390 Route No. 67— contd. ■ . • ■ ' * ' about 6 miles N. of Shiraz on the road to Isfahan. Between the gap at 2 miles and this point the plain has a maximum width of 4 miles, and is intersected by streams and artificial water-courses, more parti cularly in the eastern portion. The route runs S.-E. for 4 miles to the garden of Hadiqut-ul-Rahman and the Bagh-i-Nasrieh • thence eastwards to the Residency and Telegraph gardens • and enters Shiraz at 17 miles by the Darvazeh Bagh-i-Shah. General direction S.- E- From Talaspld the 9 m. route runs 2 miles almost due S. to the Fehlian river, which is crossed by a ford (September) 3' deep. For the first 12 j 111, miles the road as- cends gently, keeping under tne mountains which bound the valley on the E., then drops suddenly into the Shapur valley. Aftei crossing a small stream, on the bank of which is an iTYiam- zddeh, at 1| miles the track joins another running S., and passes a sulphur spring, the Chashmed-i-Ghar, and also a cir cular fort standing out on the plain called Kaieh-i-Gach Giran. At the 17th mile ford a stream 20' wide, flowing out of the Tang- i-Vastagun, a narrow gorge on the right. Mardjigan is a small Lur village. 3 A LI or KHANEH MXRZA .. 26 m. A mile beyond descend by a steep incline to the Gird-i-Bishir valley, down which is a good path on the left bank of the stream which waters it, and over 150 feet above it. The valley is about a mile wide. Cross a ridge by a steep path to avoid the Tang-i-Dusahil, the gorge through which the stream flows, and cross a stream which joins the former one by a bridge 220 feet long and 12 feet wide, known as the Pul-i-Kharabust (elevation 5,900 feet). The path now ascends in a westerlv airection ; the road is a good one, 12 feet wide, but very steep in places. The hills become steep and rocky ; the valley narrow and deep. The descent is short, but steep and rocky ; the pasture here is poor, as also the village of ’Ali. From ’Ali there is a tolerably easy road to Shush tar through Lurdigan. 4 BASAKI, .. 24 m. General direction S.- 7,850/ S.-E. Ascend gently, m.^ passing the villages of Mulla and Afghan on the right. At 7 miles cross the Gardan- i-Durman (7,036 feet). The neck is 400 yards wide and grassy. Descend gently, passing Falat, 2 miles distant, to the right; Leave the valley at 12 miles and ascend the hills on E. by a large steep incline, summit 7,900 feet; then over an undulating well-watered country into a grassy valley, 1 mile wide. At 19 miles ascend a deep and stony ravine, traverse a grassy plateau and descend to an encamping-ground below the Kuh-i-Basaki (7,850 feet). Distance to Falat 10 miles, to Simarun 30 miles. From Falat a road goes to Shira, eight stages or 160 miles. From here there is a direct road to Isihan via Nakhneh, Takun, and Qumisheh, which is said to be good. Also one via Simarun. In either case three stages to Qumisheh. 5 KINA .. ..24 m. General direction S. — 7,200b Descend a grassy 118 m. valley leading to the Kuh-i-Dinar. At 8 or 9 miles pass village of Rudabad ; 2 miles beyond ford a small stream; and then the Malbur river, J50 feet394 Route No. 68— contd. wide and 3 feet deep; very dangerous ford. Up a ravine to Sivar. At 16 miles reach the cultivated plateau and village of Numdagun. Soon after commence the ascent; the summit, 8,400 feet, reached at 22 miles. Descend to Kina. 6 SISAKHT .. 24 m. General direction S. — 7,900'. Descend the Kina 142m. valley for 1J miles and enter the Tang-i-Khafr, a narrow steep and stony ravine. Khafr is a small village at the head of a deep valley under the Kuh-i-Dlnar. A good mule road leads from here to Shiraz. The steepest part is just below the Gardan-i-Buzurg, the highest point on the road over the Kuh-i-Dinar, 10, 880 feet. The descent ist steep and stony along the right side of a ravine. Then over hill and dale, the underfeatures of the Kuh-i-Dinar, for about 10 miles when enter the undulating valley which leads the Khura. The whole of this day’s march may be consid ered easy. Khura is a Kuhgalu encampment. 8 SADAT .. .. 18 m. General direction S.-W. 7,200'. Out of the valley and 185 m. a ridge by a steep and difficult path into another valley ; at 7 miles Chinar, a walled enclosure in well-watered and cultivated valley. Then up the Tang-i-Bandarab by a steep path and into the cultivated valley of Dasht-i-Rukht. At 13 miles commence the ascent of the Gardan-i-Chashmeh Duzar, the summit of which is 9,579 feet.395 Of - 1 vV Route No. 68— contd. Descend the other side by a very steep and slippery path. Sadat is a half ruined village in a fertile and well-watered val- ley. 9 SAFAR-I-AB . 22 m. General direction W. 4,120'. Over hill and dale 207 m. Gardan-i-Mulla (8,350 feet), the descent from which is steep and difficult. The path now (viz. at 10 miles) runs under the Dalberangh hill, descends a narrow ravine, and crosses a neck (5,790 feet). Some attempts at road making have been made about here, but the most difficult places have been left untouched. Descend into the Tang-i-Nall by a rocky staircase almost impassable even for mules. Descend the Tang-i-Nall. This gorge is narrow and deep, its bed covered with huge boulders, and the track is very difficult. Reach at 22 miles the cultivated valley of Safar-i-Ab with its small village. This a difficult stage. 10 DEH DASHT .. 23 m. General direction — 2,850'. slightly S. of W. By 230 m. gentle gradient into and along the valley. At 6 miles cross a shallow sstream ; pass a cemetery, and over stony hill sides to the Tang-i-Nakhuda (God forsaken ravine). It is about 70 yards wide, with precipitous cliffs, 300 feet high. Its bed is strewn with boulders. The path crosses the stream down it a dozen times. After 4 or 5 miles emerge from the pass and traverse a comparatively open country and ascend the Kaleh Pili valley, passing several masonry runis. Kaleh Pill is a small masonry fort. Over a grassy plain to Imamzadeh Dastgird, a small ruined town, and at 23 miles reach Deh Dasht, a ruined town of some size. 11 ARrI-MARUN .. 20 m. General direction S.- — 1,400'. W. titleInfo.title: 'ROUTES IN PERSIA. VOL. III, PART I.'

physicalDescription.extent: The volume includes an index (folios 5-6) and a glossary (folios 205-206), and provides two maps in a pocket attached to the inside back cover (folios 208-209).

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the inside front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 210; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. Pagination: the volume also contains an original printed pagination sequence.

mods.abstract: The volume is a Government of India official publication entitled Routes in Persia Volume III, Part I. General Staff India 1916 (Reprint April 1918)(Simla: Printed at the Government Monotype Press, 1918).The volume contains details of land routes. The information given for each route comprises:number of route;place names forming starting point and destination of route;authority and date;number of stage;names of stages;distance in miles (intermediate and total);remarks (including precise details of the route, general geographical information, and information on smaller settlements, local peoples, religious affiliations, condition of roads, access to water, supplies of wood, and other routes).The volume also contains two maps: the first map (folio 208) is entitled Index Map to Routes in Persia Vol. III, Part I, and shows a region of central and southern Persia, indicating routes described in the volume, cities, towns, roads, tracks and paths. The map was heliozincographed at the Survey of India Offices, Calcutta, and was prepared by the Simla Drawing Office; it includes a printing statement which reads 'S.D.O. No. 1568, Sept. 1916.'.The second map (folio 209) is entitled Index Map of Gazetteer and Routes in Persia, and shows the whole of Persia with portions of adjacent countries, indicating the extents of the coverage of each volume of the Gazetteer and Routes of Persia, administrative regions and boundaries, hydrology, and major cities and towns. The map was heliozincographed at the Survey of India Offices, Calcutta, and was prepared by the Simla Drawing Office; it includes a printing statement which reads 'S.D.O. No. 1756, Jan. 1917.'.
